block.p: While these particular grandparents lost their case, the Supreme Court's decision (front page, June 6) actually grants lower courts broad powers to make decisions favorable to grandparents.

That parental autonomy deserves protection has never been seriously questioned. The plurality decision says that as long as judges apply the presumption that parents are acting in a child's best interest, visitation rights might be granted to nonparents if they can rebut this presumption.

That parental autonomy deserves protection has never been seriously questioned. The plurality decision says that as long as judges apply the presumption that parents are acting in a child's best interest, visitation rights might be granted to nonparents if they can rebut this presumption.
In this particular case, the court concluded only that the Washington State judge failed to apply the presumption in the first place.
The Supreme Court has left visitation decisions firmly in the hands of judges.
The writer is director of the Grandparent Caregiver Law Center, Brookdale Center of Aging, Hunter College.
